name: Hilton Waikoloa Village

reviews.text: definitely not the cheapest place to stay, but truly the high-gloss disney-like fantasy experience that even the locals enjoy! favorites: taking the tram, the trolley, the boat (the kids think that these are different rides), watching the dolphins, opening my sliding door to fresh ocean breezes, early morning walks from volcano rock to sandy beaches. snorkeling right outside my hotel room and actually seeing (touching) fish and turtles, the activity credit (because the activities are really expensive)....unfavorites: $15 for a hamburger!??!?!?, dusty rooms (i know it's been low vacancy but cmon, dust the furniture once in awhile), did i mention $15 for a hamburger?, 30 minute drive to the nearest town
reviews.title: where the locals vacation

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed March 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: despite the expense, we have stayed here more than 3 times. and it always is a refreshing stay.
reviews.title: Be prepared to be nickle & dimed

reviews.text: If you like a HUGE "amusement park" like resort where you can remain confined your entire stay, then this is for you. There is little that is "hawaiian" about this place - it could be anywhere that is warm with a few palm trees and a source of salt water. It is a busy place where we found it difficult to truly relax. There are trams and boats to transport you around the resort, which you will need if you don't want to spend the better part of your day getting from the parking lot to your room.
reviews.title: Really bad service, but scenic property

reviews.text: Frankly, this place just wasn't our speed. The room was OK. The hotel personnel frinedly. The restaurants too expensive. The "beach" was limited and man-made, although it is safe for kids and there were visiting turtles that seemed to like hanging around the artificial waterfall. What peeved us were the resort's undisclosed additional charges, despite our careful review of their website and other sources. For instance, self-parking is available, but at $15/day (valet is more). Internet - extra. There is a cute dolphin on your bed upon check-in that appears to be complimentary, but it is not. The free newspaper - we never saw one.
reviews.title: Don't buy the timeshare or the food
Too crowded, too corny
reviews.text: Next time, we're going somewhere less metropolitain, but more quaint and cozy.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: This place is very nice but you have to take a suite, because regular rooms s are very small...very-very small.....Be ready to walk a lot. This hotel is huge...it's like a mile from your suite to main lobby....
reviews.title: Nice and friendly....

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We stayed the end of March thru 1st week of April. They were moderatly busy as to be expected on spring break, but way under staffed. Expect luggage to take 1-2 hours to arrive at room, but thats way better than trying to lug it there yourself. Takes a good 20 mins (sometimes more) from the entrance to any room, walking or tram. Ive been telling people "its the mainlands version of what we think Hawaii should look like" Beatiful grounds and amazing art but unless you want to do whats right outside your tower, expect it to be a mini hike. I was disappointed with the tiny "beach" entrance. Beautiful, but very small and all rock. It took 30 mins to get to the "adult" pool from my room by tram. It was probably more suited for a family not wanting to leave the resort for the entirety of their stay rather than a mid 30's couple want to experiance Hawaii. Was quite disappointed with room. Great veiw of ocean and dolphines. Safe was broke, phone was very staticy (cell wouldnt get signal inside room half the time) no outlet by the bed (VERY COMFORTBLE though) only one side table. The A/C sucked. The couch was something I would of expected at Days Inn or something. The grounds were beautiful with alot of features, just really spread out. Room was soso, I guess you are more so paying for the veiws and grounds. For the same amount of money we rented a private 3,000 sq ft beachfront house with private pool in gated community in Kona, 20 miles south. Had a "real" snorkling beach 1/2 mile away on one side, and a white sand beach 1/4 mile away on other side. And it was not a hassle just to get into car to go somewhere. WIth more reasonably priced shops and resturants. $15 for a TINY glass of wine........ I guess someone has to pay for Paris's lifestlye.
reviews.title: Great 1st week at Hilton, but really enjoyed 2nd week renting private home in Kona way better

reviews.text: We spent 4 days at the village over spring break. We had a lagoon/dolphin/ocean view room with a king, sofa, and a roll away bed. I think this tower is the best location on the property. It is closest to the entrance and parking lot. It is also the closest to the large pool and water slide. Gift shops and spa are also in this part of the village. The rooms were spacious and the 4 of us never felt crowded. It is a very large resort, so plan on doing a lot of walking just to get here and there.
reviews.title: Lagoon Tower

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: One day, we took advantage of a fun pass $39 daily(offered at check-in) that gave us unlimited soda in a souvenir cup, half off lagoon beach toys, spa access, free parking, and round of putting golf for 4 people, ice cream for 4, half off tennis court time and in room high speed internet. They were out of souvenir drinks cups and had a limited amount of ice cream cups. I was told they ran out of ice cream sandwiches because they don't have space to store the ice cream. It seems absurd when you look at the size of the place! It was still worth it for the day.
reviews.title: Great if you don't mind walking...

reviews.text: We only ate at the grill by the lagoon for lunch. We all had hamburgers and they were very good. Hawaii is expensive so it is always difficult to say if the meal was worth the money. We always utilize the refrigerator to eat 2 meals in our room. Cereal/fruit for breakfast and deli meat sandwiches for lunch cut down on our food bill.
reviews.title: Great resort

reviews.text: We just spent 5 nights at the Hilton Waikoloa Village and loved it!
reviews.title: Family trip to the big island

reviews.text: We were there 15 years ago on our honeymoon and loved it back then so it was very special to bring our kids back and visit the Hilton again!
reviews.title: kids loved it!

reviews.text: It is such a great hotel for kids. Our kids are 10 and 13 and they loved the lagoon and the pools. The lagoon has so many different things for kids to try. Our kids did snorkeling, water bicycles and surf boarding. They also did the dolphin adventure.
reviews.title: Great Family-Friendly Hotel on the Big Island

reviews.text: We went to the Luau and loved the show. I don't see how anyone can go to Hawaii without doing the Luau.
reviews.title: Spent time walking

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Everyone seems to write about how big the hotel is and all the walking you have to do but I really don't find it that big. In fact many times we skipped the tram and just walked to breakfast from the Lagoon Tower.
reviews.title: Dining contingent on capacity

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We stayed at the Hilton Waikoloa for 7 nights at the beginning of May on an award stay through Hilton Honors. Overall the place was okay but I certainly would not pay to stay there with the other options in the area and I doubt I would even use hotel points again.
reviews.title: Not my first choice in the area

reviews.text: First let me address the size of the hotel grounds. Leading up to our stay I read a lot of complaints about the size and the amount of walking, which I pretty much chalked up to people being lazy on vacation. I’m Vegas veteran so I’m used to big hotels, but this place really is huge and getting around can chew up a lot of your time. From the Ocean tower, where our room was, it took 15-20 minutes to get to the car. If I had to do it again, I would stay in the Lagoon tower which would save some time and it is closer to the bigger pool area. The tram does not save you time, but it is convenient if you’re carrying a lot of stuff or sick of walking.
reviews.title: Good Value Family Resort

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed November 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The rooms are pretty standard. The main area was good size with enough room for the king bed, a sofa, coffee table, desk and still some space to spare. The bathroom is tiny. You basically had to step into the tub to shut the door so you could use the toilet. The first room they gave us had to be the worst in the hotel. It was literally on top of the tram stop and next to the ice machine. We could hear a lot of tram noise from the room and the lanai….so much for an upgrade because of my Hilton Gold status. At first they told us they only had a room with two beds available but eventually found another King on the ground floor. This was fine except anytime you wanted to sit on the (very small) lanai you were overrun by cats. In fairness to the Hilton this seems to be a problem for all the resorts in the area. I would definitely recommend requesting a room on a higher floor.
reviews.title: Really enjoyed the Hilton Waikoloa Village

reviews.text: If you’re planning on staying at a decent resort in Hawaii, you can expect to pay high prices for most things. The Hilton prices are really over the top though. We stayed at the Ritz on Maui and somehow they can charge $5 for a beer at the pool but the cheapest option at the Hilton was $7. A six pack of the local Kona beer was $13 at the much nicer Mauna Kea Resort down the road and it was $25 at the Hilton. $4 for a 12 ounce fountain soda. $16/day for internet. $15/day self parking.
reviews.title: An Oasis among Black Lava

reviews.text: The hotel grounds are pretty impressive with the dolphins, waterfalls, lagoon, exotic birds etc.. There is a small adult pool inside the ocean tower as well as the two bigger pools. The lagoon pool is the bigger and more spectacular of the two and is adjacent to the lagoon. We weren’t really impressed with the “beach” by the lagoon, it is basically just a narrow strip of sand that seemed most appealing for those with small kids.
reviews.title: AWESOME PLACE
Noisy, crowded tourist trap
reviews.text: The rooms weren't soundproof. Ongoing construction. Too crowded. Halls smelled like mold.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed November 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Stayed at the Hilton on Nov 21, 2008 and thanks to all of the accurate trip advisor reviews I'd read, I knew exactly what to expect. Knowing it was a beautiful place but very big and inconvenient to get around, on-site food was outrageously priced, parking was inconvenient and there was no beach, we weren't disappointed. We chose to stay only one night for these reasons, then checked into a condo in Kolea for the rest of the week. (Kolea is next door, I wrote a long review about that property.) It's all about expectations....I can see why some people would absolutely love the Hilton and I can see why some people would be miserable. We arrived around 9 pm, tired and hungry and had to walk a long way to find a place that was open, just to get a sandwich. One sandwich, no sides was $17. Delicious though! Total bill for 2 sandwiches, one beer and one diet coke was $52 plus a tip. A large family could spend a massive amount of money on food if they were staying here but if money isn't an object, heck, why not?
reviews.title: Beautiful Resort But No Beach

reviews.text: Read all the Hilton reviews and if you don't mind walking a lot or waiting for trams and paying a lot to eat on-site, you will love the place! Just note that eating off-site is very inconvenient as it as a very long walk to the restaurants and food courts at the Kings and Queens shops. Your only other option is to take the shuttles, which only ran every half hour, take a long walk to self-park or wait to get your car from valet parking and constantly tip the valets everytime you need your car (on top of the $21 per day for valet parking).
reviews.title: loved it!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Just a note...for those who don't like the idea of long walks, tram waits, etc., check out the Marriot....it is a much smaller property, has a nice beach, snorkelling, and is conveniently located next door to Queen's and King's shops for easy access to off-site food.
reviews.title: Wonderful resort but bring your walking shoes

likes.disliked: — The transportation (train, boat) is not frequent enough

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: If you have time to relax, and not be in a hurry, this place is great! Yes, sometimes you must wait for the tram or boat, but you can always walk through the corridors with great art and art pieces to look at, and there are always koi ponds, flamingos, etc. to keep your interest.
reviews.title: Beautiful Resort

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I have such mixed thoughts about this resort. We stayed here because we were at a conference at this hotel and the conference rate was great. Depending on the type of traveler you are, this may be the resort for you. But it wasn't the right one for us.
reviews.title: Mixed review

reviews.text: First, it is about 40 minutes from Kailua, which is where most of the action is (e.g., restaurants, diving, etc.) And it literally took us 15 minutes just to get from the room to the parking lot. If you are the type of person who likes to just relax at the resort, then you might not notice this until you are leaving to go to the airport, but 6 of the 7 days we were there we left the property. Between the walk/monorail to the parking lot and then the drive to Kailua, I spent more time commuting on vacation than I do commuting to work.
reviews.title: Great big beautiful resort with some major flaws....

reviews.text: So why do I give it 4 stars? Because for what it is, HIlton does it really well. The pools (especially the big one) are beautiful, the landscaping is spectacular, the rooms were spotless, cleaning was great, etc.
reviews.title: Beautiful hotel, beautiful place!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The downside to the resort is that I kept thinking of it as a low-end all-inclusive that doesn't want you to eat a lot of food or drink a lot. There were few restaurants compared to the size of the property and some weren't open at times you would expect them to be. The pool bars were relatively small, and the lounge, where I would have liked to spend a few hours during the hottest hours of the day, wasn't open during the day.
reviews.title: Wonderful Hawaii Vacation

reviews.text: I think this is probably an excellent place for families.
reviews.title: Really Amazing for Families and Relaxing

reviews.text: We stayed here for 1 night on our recent trip to the Big Island. The line to check-in on a Sunday was very slow. It was spring break so crowds were to be expected, but there were only 2 people working the front desk. Seems like they would be better prepared for a rush at typical check-in time at 4PM. Stood in line for at least 30 minutes, which wasn't enjoyable after the 6 hour flight from the mainland with our 1 year-old. Checked in and were automatically upgraded to an ocean front room. After finishing with the check-in we realized we had to take a tram to our room. Stood around for another 15 minutes waiting for the tram to pick us up and go to our room. Once on the tram we were whisked away to the Ocean Tower where we went immediately to the Cantina restaurant before going to our room. The food was okay, service was marginal. They had a trumpet player playing along to a midi machine that was straight out of the 80's. Totally cheesy. The walk to our room exposed that this hotel needs some work. When you pay $300 per night, it should be nearly flawless. But the Ocean Tower looks like a run down motel on the outside. Our room was very nice with an amazing view of the ocean. The lanai was pretty small and the patio furniture looked like it hadn't been cleaned in a very long time. There was a planter box off to one side of the lanai that had garbage in it and no plants. The pool area on the other side of the resort was incredible. That seemed like where all the action is. Overall, this place was too big, too crowded, and too run-down for our liking. It is built to entertain the masses, but little details were overlooked that makes it not worth visiting.
reviews.title: Not our cup of tea

reviews.text: I just went for my fourth time to this hotel. First time 17 years ago on my honey moon and then two times with my son when he was little. Now he is 14 and we returned for spring break. The property is LARGE - encompassing three separate hotel "groups" that are connected by waterways and a monorail. You can walk, boat or ride between the proproerties, although the boat has limits hours and the monorail is also not that frequent. They are the Lagoon towers, The Palace Towers and the Ocean Towers. The most desirable is the Lagoon, then Palace and then Ocean. That is because of the length of distance between them and the "action" aras of the hotel which is the lagoon, the main pools and the dolphin enclosures. Because it was spring break nd I did not call until to months before the trip, we were in the Ocean tower because everything else was booked. The rooms are nice, but boy you have to walk a LONG way. I seem to have forgotten how far. There were no porters when we checked in and we had to drag big suitcases a lng way - even though we were able to lug them on the monorail. Ironically, despit having a really nice time otherwise, this experience - and pulling out my shoulder luggin the big bags, clouds my feelings about the trip. They must know when the main flights are coming in and how many people will be checking in - and sure enough a long, long line to check in. Gone arth days when they put leis around you at check in - and nay two people for about 30 families checking in... NO Porters... This theme carried through the stay. Lovely hotel, lots of great art, but few people to serve you. Wait time for the cereal place - little breakfast place in AM about 45 min to one hour in the AM because they had one person. Wait time at the Lagoon grill to get waited on to take your order - 30 minutes before they knew y were there etc etc... The hotel is maintained, and clean and orderly but they AR definaty cutting back on labor and that has diminished the experience.
reviews.title: Nice, but it needs more personnel in this large property

reviews.text: DO go to the dolphin experience. Third time for my son, and just as much fun. $255 dollars a person however.
reviews.title: So many better options out there

reviews.text: I've stayed at the Hilton Waikoloa several years in a row for the Lavaman Triathlon, and the service just keeps declining. The hotel is so spread out that the amount of walking you have to do daily is ridiculous (think at least 1-2 miles), and this year, the shuttles just never seemed to come. Traveling ON the property literally adds 15-20 minutes to every task; not the way I want to spend time on my vacation. The options for breakfast are almost nil unless you want microwaved fast food (literally, you put it in the microwave yourself like you're at 7-11), or the $30 buffet. There's not even somewhere to just grab a cup of coffee unless you want the swill made in your room. On several occasions we called the concierge for info only to have the phone ring incessantly or get a voice mail. With the exception of housekeeping staff, who always had a friendly hello, most staff was relatively cool and unfriendly. Only 2 of the pools have bars, and those bars don't open until noon (where can a girl get a mimosa??). I can't think of a single reason to go back.
reviews.title: Amazing Family Vacation

reviews.text: The resort is amazing with plenty to do for the whole family!
reviews.title: Great Place to stay

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: This is a huge resort in an ex excellent location. The weather is always perfect here. The trams and boats around the resort are fun. Take the time to walk through and check out the incredible historical artifacts the resort displays. The rooms aren't huge but they are clean, up dated and have excellent views. We stayed in the lagoon tower overlooking the dolphin lagoon and out to the ocean. The ocean tower has the kids activities center as well as a small adults only pool. But the boat goes right next to in so its kinda loud and smells like gasoline. The pool by the lagoon tower is huge and spectacular with a great kids area. the kohala pool has slides for kids and nice covered cabanas and hammocks. The food in the resort is, of course, pricey but there are restaurants and more shopping across the street. There isn't much night life here. The area is more about outdoor activities and excellent beaches. The beach at the Hilton is a man made bit on the lagoon. There is a free shuttle that goes to A Bay all day. I highly recommend driving down to Hapuna Beach for excellent sand, swimming and snorkeling on the southern side. For Hawaiian shopping be sure to check out the international market in Kailua Kona.
reviews.title: Beautiful and Perfect!

likes.disliked: — not a great on site beach

reviews.text: Kamuela Provision Company has incredible food and atmosphere. Dress nice and get there at 5:30 for a prime patio table. The macadamia nut kahlua mahi mahi is excellent.
reviews.title: Nice but Expensive

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Just returned from 11 days in Hawaii, with the last 4 nights at the Hilton. It's pretty much as advertised: very large, spread-out property with very expensive retaurants, elaborate (but cold) pools and waterslides, and rooms that are pleasant, but in need of some updating.
reviews.title: This place, is NOT Hawai'i.

likes.disliked: — Icky birds in the Palace terrace resaurant p__p all over food.

reviews.title: Beautiful Disney like grounds but you'll mostly want to eat elsewhere
reviews.text: We only ate one dinner on-site at the Chinese restaurant Kirin. Food was pretty good, but as with everything else, much more money than what you would expect to pay on the mainland.

If you have younger kids, you probably will want to ask to stay at the Lagoon Tower which is closest to the largest pool and slide. If you want some exercise and don't care as much about proximity to those areas, the Palace or Ocean Towers would be ok, especially if you don't mind walking a bit.
reviews.title: Stay somewhere else and just walk the grounds

likes.liked: — The grounds are nice to walk. The lagoon was fun.
likes.disliked: — The rooms are small and need updating. The pool was freezing. Not worth the price. Can get a beautiful condo for less.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Okay, we went to this Hilton using our HHonors points. It is the only Hilton on the big Island and we read the reviews before going, hoping for the best. We were there six nights.
reviews.title: Not my favorite Hilton by far!

likes.disliked: — Amount of time wasted getting round the resort

reviews.text: Good things:
reviews.title: Beware: Price gouging to the extreme

reviews.text: The resort and grounds are absolutely beautiful.
reviews.title: Somthing for Everyone...

likes.disliked: — they could better mark the wheelchair access..they were there but a way out and hard to find.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Our room maid was very helpful and tried to make up for other service shortfalls.
reviews.title: We were not disappointed !!!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: If you are looking for a resort to stay at and spend all your time there, and money is no object - this would be a great choice!
reviews.title: Great Place, but food expensive

likes.liked: — Beautiful resorts with plants, birds, etc.
likes.disliked: — Outgarous food prices, $20 a day to self park - $25 for valet

reviews.text: I stayed at this resort in conjunction with the Lavaman Triathlon. The setting is beautiful and the small village with shops is only a 5 minute walk. The resort grounds are very large and it can take a good 10-15 minutes to get from one side to the other. The tram is extremely slow (you can walk as fast or faster), but it is convenient when you are hauling your own luggage. I recommend having your luggage delivered to your room versus carrying it yourself. The resort is very family-oriented, which I was not expecting. If you are looking for a place that is adult focused this is not it. There were many children and it's pretty much lights out after 10:00pm. The pool cabanas were a good deal ($50 for half day and it includes snacks and bottled water).
reviews.title: Family friendly resort in beautiful setting

reviews.text: It can be VERY windy on this part of the island, so be prepared!
reviews.title: Hilton Waikoloa is a great place to bring kids!

reviews.text: My husband and I decided our kids were old enough to explore and wander around Kilauea volcano on the Big Island. I had been prior and loved the Big Island. We decided on the Hilton Waikoloa Hotel b/c it was big and with lots to do and thought the kids would love it. And they did! Beautiful landscaping throughout, decent rooms and a place to swim with dolphins. Beware, it's massive, but I never had any problem finding lounges by the 2 pools or lagoon. We had a beatiful ground floor room right above Dolphin Quest so we used our sliding glass door as a way to get around the property. Otherwise, it would be a trek! You'll get plenty of walking in. A couple complaints: pools are not heated and are VERY cold--so cold that no one goes in. We didn't mind since the lagoon (fed directly by the ocean) is warm and fun. Restaurants are only average and very expensive. We had a rental car so we tried to eat off property as much as we could. On our way in from the airport, we stopped at Costco and purchased a cheap icechest and breakfast/lunch makings & LIQUOR, so were were pretty self contained other than dinner. We found lots of hidden dive/gems in and around Kona/Waimea, so dinner was never outrageous! Lots to do, great location, great weather. Fun times! Make sure you stay in the Lagoon Tower on the back side ground level. Will make your trip sooo much better!
reviews.title: Overall Lousy Place

reviews.text: The hotel is huge and getting around was very annoying. The tram is slower than walking and the boats come very infrequently. The pools are freezing cold. Our 5 yr old daughter would not even go in. If you like the beach forget it...they dont have one. This hotel could be anywhere in world..nothing hawaiiish about it. The grounds are pretty but thats about it. The service is awful and the restaurants are expensive and awful as we tried almost all of them. We left the hotel most days to explore some beautiful other beaches like hapuna and mauna kea and were upset we were not at one of the beautiful beaches. I would not even recommend for kids. The housekeeping was awful as well as the room was really dusty and there were hairs everywhere. The blankets had numerous holes in them as well.
reviews.title: good choice for families

reviews.text: We spent 5 nights here for spring break. Hilton is not a chain from which I expect very much, especially after our less than stellar stay at the Hilton Hawaiian Village (HHV) in Honolulu last spring. I was, however, pleasantly surprised. What this Hilton has that the HHV didn't is: 1) a lot more land (typical of an outer island resort vs. a Waikiki one) 2) better overall attitude amongst its staff, i.e., more smiles. We used the hotel's 50 Years of Aloha package, where the 5th night is $50 and you get a $50 resort credit.
reviews.title: Will you like this place? Hard to say, but it's certainly unique

reviews.text: I did not like this hotel. I read the other reviews about how big the property was and how long it took to get the tram or boat. This was not my issue.
reviews.title: Bad service, bad location, can't recommend

likes.disliked: — The service, the value for what I paid

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: As a higher end resort property, I expected much more. The service was terrible. I understand the Spirit of Aloha makes the locals relaxed, however, they were rude and had a hard time providing basic service. Every concierge I asked for help for activities off the property basically acted as if I was asking for their first born.
reviews.title: Improved

reviews.text: The property was pretty, but inconviently located if you wanted to do anything out of Kailua-Kona.
reviews.title: Hilton Waikoloa Village

likes.liked: — Mega resort with spectacular ocean views
likes.disliked: — Sprawling; difficult to enter and leave property; resort is very isolated - far from Kona

reviews.text: I wish I could recommend this Hilton, but I can't.
reviews.title: vacation

likes.disliked: — the view, expensive food, and no beach.

reviews.text: Great return trip. Excellent service. Some changes were made at the hotel that I thought were great. Happy hour was added at the lagoon grill and the bar was open till 7 pm. Golf courses had discounted rates. Staff was excellent.
reviews.title: Worst Customer Service I've Ever Experienced

reviews.text: Certainly not family friendly, very good apparently if you are one of their large corporate renters, rooms booked and paid for months in advance by families not ready hours after check in time and not the room type requested, transportation system broken down frequently and food costs for families ridiculous,even small services including internet time money money and more money.
reviews.title: Very Poorly Managed Resort

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed March 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The Dolphin Quest Programme Is Run By an Excellent and Decicated Staff and Handled Very Professionally, Wonderful Experience PITY the Hotel isn't that efficient.
reviews.title: An Awesome Place---Not For Everyone

reviews.text: This wasn’t my first time at this jumbo-sized Hawaiian version of Disneyland. We had stayed here a few years back and spent the requisite days marveling at the size of this behemoth, the shuttle boats that run on hidden tracks and the sleek train that ferry’s the masses back and forth. Whoever conceived this place was thinking in google-speed and crafted a true masterpiece upon the lava. Plenty of activities, unbelievable art collection, happy dolphins, great views and kids will never, ever get bored here---I promise.
reviews.title: Hawaii's version of Disneyland! Great for kids.

reviews.text: But after the first stay, this second one was tinged slightly. Things were “off” and the ever-faithful Hilton Waikoloa was akin to a beautiful lady who had wandered into the fringes of a bad neighborhood. The room was dirty, nobody answers the phones and some of the services and food had been scaled back. The predictable timeshare hustle was cranked up a notch, the front desk was way understaffed and the food inconsistent. But at the end of the day, it is still an unbelievable place and great for children and/or Hawaii first-timers. But if you’re sans children and have sampled other resorts on this coast (like the Fairmont or Hapuna), you may be disappointed. I’m not saying stay away, just be prepared and understand what you are getting. My wife calls it a wayward cruise ship that has beached itself permanently.
reviews.title: Great Get-Away Hotel

reviews.text: Personal it is not---you are a reservation number and contributor to a daily occupancy statistic. It’s understandable. After all, it is a very large resort and fields huge amounts of people in and out every day. Just stand in the lobby and watch the train pull in and discharge hundreds while loading up a fresh herd en masse. It made us feel like we were being processed through a cannery; being joined by waves of conventioneers from Mid-western states that begin in vowels, wearing identical leis, name badges and wondering about the limit on the credit card.
reviews.title: Very expensive, nickle & dimed you to death

description: Hilton Waikoloa Village is located within the Waikoloa Beach Resort area on the sunny Kohala Coast on Hawaii's Big Island - just 18 miles from the Kona International Airport. It is a unique 62 acre oceanfront resort with trams and canal boats transporting you throughout the resort. Enjoy a serene snorkeling lagoon, interactive dolphin encounters, spectacular pools with waterslides, the Kohala Spa, exciting shopping and dining, and golf at one of two championship golf courses.
